items.title: Suppress printing to stdout/stderr
items.body:
Thanks for the great library. We use Wand like this:

```python
# XXX: lines below have to stay in this order, or Wand leaks / crashes.
with wand.image.Image(blob=pdf_bytes, format='pdf', resolution=50) as all_pages:
    for page_no, page in enumerate(all_pages.sequence, start=1):
        with wand.image.Image(page) as img:
            yield img
```

We see our logs polluted by thousands of lines like:

```
**** Error: Unknown operator: %%EOF
                Output may be incorrect.
```

Which we suspect come from ImageMagick via Wand.  

What's the best way to stop IM / Wand from printing to stdout and stderr? …while not affecting other functions using this generator, that actually do need stdout+stderr.

-----

Using Wand 0.5.9, IM 6.9.10-23 (Ubuntu 20.04), gs 9.50.

items.title: Including doc and tests in source distributions
items.body:
Hi again Eric,
I'm about to add wand to Gentoo and, now that I'm done with the tests, I have one more question: what do you think of adding doc and tests to source distributions?

Gentoo (and I think Debian as well) tend to rely on PyPI tarballs instead of GitHub's for building packages and since we run tests / build docs, we need those to be present.

I normally create a PR for that kind of issue but seeing how it will decuple the tarball size, I thought it would be wiser to ask you first.

Additional question: do you plan on releasing a new version soon? I'm especially interested in the float test fix and the removal of `README.rst` from `data_files`. If not, it's no problem; I'll backport the individual patches.

items.title: Add an option to disable failing PDF tests on Archlinux and Gentoo
items.body:
Arch and Gentoo have disabled PDF operations for security reasons, this results in 3 failing tests:
```
FAILED tests/image_properties_test.py::test_resolution_set_03 - wand.exceptions.PolicyError: atte...     
FAILED tests/image_properties_test.py::test_resolution_set_04 - wand.exceptions.PolicyError: atte...
FAILED tests/image_test.py::test_read_with_colorspace - wand.exceptions.PolicyError: attempt to p...     
```
The exact error is ```wand.exceptions.PolicyError: attempt to perform an operation not allowed by the security policy `PDF' @ error/constitute.c/IsCoderAuthorized/412```.

Would it be possible to skip those based on either of these?
* the value of an environment variable
* a pytest option, [like tox does with network-dependent tests](https://github.com/tox-dev/tox/commit/a7d77114733559b2a7d8bec17f2488b89c55fd14#diff-b4a64c93d6d2c2413095373cbadcb62c) using [pytest_addoption](https://docs.pytest.org/en/latest/example/parametrize.html#generating-parameters-combinations-depending-on-command-line)

items.title: page offsets after trim() are off by one compared to the CLI's
items.body:
Hi,
I have `ImageMagick 7.0.10-10` and Wand `0.5.9` (I also tried the latest git master).
I am running this very simple program with the attached [test.png](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4833332/81455052-4d827400-918e-11ea-8642-dbf26434a1ba.png) file:
```py
#!/usr/bin/env python3
from wand.image import Image

with Image(filename="test.png") as img:
    print(img.size)
    print(img.page)
    img.trim()
    print(img.size)
    print(img.page)
```

It returns the following:
```
(10, 10)
(10, 10, 0, 0)
(2, 3)
(12, 12, 5, 4)
```

On the other hand, `convert -trim test.png info:` returns `test.png PNG 2x3 10x10+4+3 8-bit sRGB 95B 0.000u 0:00.000`.

Am I missing an extra step or are the page offsets off by one? I'm also curious about the width and height of the page, why did they increase?

items.title: /etc/papersize openfiles ulimit
items.body:
Hi,

I inherited this block of code which fails when there is a large number of pdf's to convert.

It seems to be keeping the /etc/papersize file open for the length of the script. I can see that the file is lots of times in lsof until it hits the ulimit and then dies.

As a workaround I've bumped the ulimit to 50000 which seems to work but my VM eventually slows to a crawl.

```python
for f in os.scandir(pdf_files_dir):
    if f.name.endswith(".pdf"):
      logger.info(f"Converting {f.name} to PNG")
      temp_png = f.path.replace(pdf_files_dir, png_files_dir)
      temp_png = temp_png.replace(".pdf", ".png")
      with Image(filename=f.path, resolution=300) as pdf:
        with pdf.convert("png") as png:
          png.save(filename=temp_png)
```

items.title: Wand/ImageMagicks defaults to MVG instead of Inkscape
items.body:
When I run `convert protests-back.svg protests.png` or `with wand.image.Image(filename=filepath)` I get: 

    convert: unable to read font `helvetica' @ error/annotate.c/RenderFreetype/1391.
    convert: non-conforming drawing primitive definition `letter-spacing' @ 
    error/draw.c/RenderMVGContent/4434.

This is confusing, as I expect IM to use my installed Inkscape to open svgs and export them to pngs. Inkscape doesn't have problems with `letter-spacing`, `text`, or `flow`s.

I understand that Imagemagick relies on the `delegates.xml` file to detail what programs to use where, do I need to update this file to modify svg?

`delegates.xml`:

    <delegate decode="svg" 
    command=""rsvg-convert" -o "%o" "%i""/>
    
    <!-- Change export-png to export-file for inkscape 1.0+ -->
    
    <delegate decode="svg:decode" stealth="True" 
    command=""inkscape" "%s" 
    --export-png="%s" 
    --export-dpi="%s" 
    --export-background="%s" 
    --export-background-opacity="%s" > "%s" 2>&1"/>

`convert  -list format | grep -i svg` gives:

    MSVG  SVG       rw+   ImageMagick's own SVG internal renderer
    SVG  SVG       rw+   Scalable Vector Graphics (XML 2.9.4)
    SVGZ  SVG       rw+   Compressed Scalable Vector Graphics (XML 2.9.4)
  
I was able to get it to use Inkscape in the past, or at least something that doesn't give `letter-spacing` and `flow` errors, but I reinstalled everything to try to isolate the dependencies of the installation process.

Thanks for any and all help yall!

items.title: crop() gets wrong coordinates after trim()

milestone.title: Wand 0.6.0
milestone.description: Focus on resource improvements, and reference management.

items.body:
After a trim() call is made, crop() results in incorrect sized images when using left or top coordinates close to the corner.

Repro:
Create a blank image, put some text on it, then cut it up in to quarters - correct functionality.
Create a blank image, put some text on it, trim it, then cut it up in to quarters - incorrect functionality.

Repro code:
```
#!/usr/bin/python3

from wand.drawing import Drawing
from wand.image import Image

draw=Drawing()
img=Image(width = 500, height = 500)

draw.font = '/usr/share/fonts/opentype/freefont/FreeSansBold.otf'
draw.font_size = 675
draw.text( 0, img.height, "A")

draw(img)
print("Original full size:    " + str( img[:, :] ))
print("Original top left:     " + str( img[:int( img.width / 2 ), :int( img.height / 2 ) ] ))
print("Original bottom right: " + str( img[ int( img.width / 2 ):, int( img.height / 2 ):] ))

img.trim()
print("Trimmed full size:     " + str( img[:, :] ))
print("Trimmed top left:      " + str( img[:int( img.width / 2 ), :int( img.height / 2 ) ] ))
print("Trimmed bottom right:  " + str( img[ int( img.width / 2 ):, int( img.height / 2 ):] ))

# The 'A' trims down to 458x492 - a quarter should be 229x246
print("Trimmed hard-coded top left:     " + str( img[  0:229,   0:246] ))
print("Trimmed hard-coded bottom right: " + str( img[229:458, 246:492] ))

```

Output:
```
Original full size:    <wand.image.Image: 0a595b4 '' (500x500)>
Original top left:     <wand.image.Image: 48f355c '' (250x250)>
Original bottom right: <wand.image.Image: b54cc59 '' (250x250)>
Trimmed full size:     <wand.image.Image: c185e46 '' (458x492)>
Trimmed top left:      <wand.image.Image: 7177447 '' (222x237)>
Trimmed bottom right:  <wand.image.Image: 9629632 '' (229x246)>
Trimmed hard-coded top left:     <wand.image.Image: 7177447 '' (222x237)>
Trimmed hard-coded bottom right: <wand.image.Image: 9629632 '' (229x246)>
```

```

items.title: Homebrew (Mac) installation with --with-liblqr option fails

milestone.title: Wand 0.6.0
milestone.description: Focus on resource improvements, and reference management.

items.body:
It seems like the `--with-liblqr` option was removed from Homebrew. Trying to install it gives the following error:

```
$ brew install imagemagick --with-liblqr
[ extensive usage information for brew command omitted here ]
Error: invalid option: --with-liblqr
```
[Liblqr is still available](https://formulae.brew.sh/formula/liblqr) as a separate Homebrew formula but the option in ImageMagick was removed. AFAIK, there is currently no way to use liquide-rescale on a Mac.

items.title: Unable to remove transparency when converting PDF to TIFF

milestone.title: Wand 0.6.0
milestone.description: Focus on resource improvements, and reference management.

items.body:
Using the following code:

```python
from wand.image import Image, Color


with Image(filename='5-page-pdf.pdf', resolution=200, colorspace='gray', background=Color('white')) as img:
    img.type = "grayscale"
    img.format = "tiff"
    img.compression = "lzw"
    img.alpha_channel = 'off'
    img.save(filename="test.tiff")
```

I get a TIFF that has transparency enabled on pages 2-4. I've tried other things to remove the alpha channel ('remove', using a context manager on the sequence to remove it on the individual SingleImages, etc), but nothing seems to work. I've pasted links to the original PDF and the TIFF this produces.

I should note that imageMagick has no issues when I use the following command:

```
convert -density 200 5-page-pdf.pdf -type grayscale -compress lzw test.tiff
```

So I'm not sure if this is a bug in wand or something else.
[PDF](https://moscon.org/pdf/5-page-pdf.pdf)
[TIFF](https://moscon.org/pdf/test.tiff)

items.body:
- Wand version: 0.5.8
- Python Version: 3.7.6
- OS: Windows 10

When trying to load an image with a long file path, the wand module throws a FileNotFoundError.

Example - the code below:

```

```

Any chance wand could support long file names ?

There is a typo in `image.py:671`:

```python
if MAGICK_VERSION_NUMBER >= 0x700:  # pragma: no cover
    IMAGE_TYPES = ('undefined', 'bilevel', 'grayscale', 'grayscalemalpha',
                   'palette', 'palettealpha', 'truecolor', 'truecoloralpha',

from wand.font import Font

with Image(width=1920, height=1080,background=Color('black')) as img:

    with Drawing() as draw:
        draw.font = 'Arial'
        draw.fill_color = Color('#F2F2F2')
        draw.font_size = 60

        draw.text(10,200, 'test')
        draw.draw(img)
#         img.colorspace='rgb'

        img.save(filename='test.tiff')

items.title: Update the Documentation for the latest builds of ImageMagick

milestone.title: Wand 0.6.0
milestone.description: Focus on resource improvements, and reference management.

items.body:
Comming back to Issue #454 , I have tested multiple ImageMagick binary builds for Windows. 
The listed builds in the [documentation](http://docs.wand-py.org/en/latest/guide/install.html#install-imagemagick-on-windows) result in a sort of artificial jitter as seen in the example further down after compositing a sequence. 
Installing the latest imagemagick build at this time [ImageMagick-7.0.9-22-Q16-x86-dll.exe](https://imagemagick.org/script/download.php) however, solves this issue.
Updating the docs might be saving some frustration to whomever might cross the same issue.

items.title: Animation flickering using composite_channel
items.body:
Using a high framerate gif with transparency to overlay a static image, some of the compositing operators seem to have a strange flicker effect at one point in time for the gif, showing only the underlying image for a few frames
```python 
from wand.image import Image

with Image() as dst_image:
    with Image(filename="overlay.gif") as overlay_image, Image(filename="background.png") as bg:
        for frame in overlay_image.sequence:

            frame.composite_channel("all_channels", image=bg, operator="dst_over", gravity="center")
            dst_image.sequence.append(frame)

    dst_image.save(filename="output.gif")

items.title: Would be nice to add format to Image.save
items.body:
I've run into a scenario where I had to save the generated image in a string buffer. The Image.save method could not determine the right format and was bailing out. I ended up using the following:
`out_file.write(img.make_blob(format='png'))`
It would be nice to add format directly to the save method, so that one can write it like:
`img.save(out_file, format='png')`

items.title: add dropshadow
items.body:
I'm porting a bash script that uses `convert` to Python. The command I'm having trouble with is:

```
convert "input.png" \
\( -clone 0 -background "#000000" -shadow 34x12+2+2 \) \
\( -clone 0 -background "#000000" -shadow 34x12-2-2 \) \
-reverse -background "#ff0000" -layers merge +repage "shadow.png"
```
I tried to use the `shadow()` method like this:

```python
with Image(filename=str(self.path)) as trimmed_img:
    # resize
    trimmed_img.transform(resize=f'{self.max_width}x{self.max_height}>')

    # trim transparent pixels
    trimmed_img.trim()
    trimmed_img.reset_coords()

    trimmed_img.save(filename='trimmed.png')

    with trimmed_img.clone() as shadow_img:
        # add drop shadow
        shadow_img.shadow(
            alpha=34,
            sigma=12,
            x=2,
            y=2
        )
        shadow_img.save(filename='shadow.png')

        # draw background rectangle
        with Color(self.color) as bg:
            with Image(width=self.output_width, height=self.output_height, background=bg) as bg_img:
                bg_img.save(filename='boxed.png')

                # center shadow on rectangle
                bg_img.composite(image=shadow_img, gravity='center')
        
                # center painting on rectangle
                bg_img.composite(image=trimmed_img, gravity='center')

                # export
                bg_img.resolution = self.dpi
                bg_img.units = 'pixelsperinch'
                bg_img.compression_quality = self.quality
                bg_img.format = 'jpeg'
                bg_img.depth = 8
                bg_img.save(filename='output.jpg')
```

but this produces an image with only the shadow layer, not the image overlaid on top of the shadow.

Any idea?

items.title: Resolution rounding
items.body: Is there any possibility to open image with selected units parameter? Or, at least, return resolution value without rounding? I tried to open image with selected units parameter: ``` from wand.image import Image as Wand_Image f = open('path_to_image/Test_adobe.png', 'rb') image = Wand_Image(blob=f, units='pixelsperinch') ``` But as a result, _resolution_ didn't changed and _units_ became 'pixelsperinch': ``` print(image.resolution) # returns (28, 28) print(image.units) # returns 'pixelsperinch' ``` From Photoshop dpi is exactly 72 (or 28,346 in Pixel/Centimiter) On other hand, I couldn't use convert formula from Centimiters to Inches because in resolution() function there is rounding of value - in my example it's 2.54 * 28 = **71.12** - far away from expected **72 dpi** (link to commit [Wand resolution](https://github.com/emcconville/wand/pull/58/commits/3e4eefb73f561ad9ffeafebd874c9991adaefa46) ): ``` def resolution(self): """(:class:`tuple`) Resolution of this image. .. versionadded:: 0.3.0 """ x = ctypes.c_double() y = ctypes.c_double() r = library.MagickGetImageResolution(self.wand, x, y) if not r: # pragma: no cover self.raise_exception() return int(x.value), int(y.value) ``` Example of test image: [Test_adobe.png.zip](https://github.com/emcconville/wand/files/3911260/Test_adobe.png.zip) Shell ImageMagick command 'identify -verbose path_to_image/Test_adobe.png' returns: Resolution: 28.35x28.35 Thank you!

labels.description: Requires a functionality / behavior change outside of this python project

items.body:
I'm trying to migrate CMYK → RGB image converter from PHP into Python. However the ICC profile added to input image [per documentation](http://docs.wand-py.org/en/0.5.7/whatsnew/0.5.html#import-extract-profiles) does not seem to be applied during conversion.

PHP code
```php
$imgc = new \Imagick();
$imgc->readImage($this->dir.$img);
$rgbProfile = file_get_contents(public_path('icm/').'srgb.icc');
$imgc->profileImage('icc', $rgbProfile);

$imgc->transformImageColorspace(\Imagick::COLORSPACE_RGB);
```

Attempted Python code
```python
layout = Image(filename=layout_path)
rgb_icc = open('/icm/srgb.icc', 'rb')
layout.profiles['icc'] = rgb_icc.read()
layout.transform_colorspace('rgb')   # setting 'srgb' results in the same image
```

Input CMYK file
![input](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5619390/67205910-5e99ac80-f419-11e9-81f9-a598db368f27.jpg)
Expected result generated with PHP converter
![expected-result](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5619390/67205908-5e99ac80-f419-11e9-85e0-5ff2ca28e5b7.jpg)

![actual-result](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/5619390/67205904-5e011600-f419-11e9-8700-96e1f4f9f000.jpg)

Any advice on how can I get ICC profile applied before transformation?

items.title: Implementing caption with draw - Looks a little weird
items.body:
I'm rendering text using `image.caption` instead of `draw.text` as it fits my use case a lot better. Unfourtantly I was having an issue with the text rendering over elements created using `draw` (For example a `rectangle`)

I reimplemented caption to composite using `draw.composite` instead of `image.composite`, like so:

```
def textboard(draw, text, left, top, width, height, font, gravity):
    with WandImage() as textboard:
        library.MagickSetSize(textboard.wand, width, height)
        textboard.font = font
        textboard.gravity = gravity or None
        with Color('transparent') as background_color:
            library.MagickSetBackgroundColor(textboard.wand,
                                             background_color.resource)
        textboard.read(filename=b'caption:' + text.encode('utf-8'))
        draw.composite(
            operator="atop",
            left=left,
            top=top,
            width=textboard.width,
            height=textboard.height,
            image=textboard
        )
```

Antialias is set to True on my `font` object

This solved the issue of getting the text to render over rectangles/images but not the text looks odd.

Here's what the text looks like when using the built-in `image.caption`:

items.title: ImageMagick-7 support for Image.frame
items.body:
ImageMagick-7 introduces the `compose` operator as an argument. This was not implemented with `Image.frame` method, and results in some undefined behaviour. Like [unexpected grayscale](https://stackoverflow.com/q/57275316/438117).

Fix is to include support for `compose` parameter, and default it to `OverCompositeOp` to match the CLI behaviour.

items.title: Respect background parameter in Image constructor
items.body:
This is a long & outstanding issue. Introduced with #184, wand defaults read operations with a transparent background.

```py
# wand.image.Image.__init__
with Color('transparent') as bg:  # FIXME: parameterize this
     result = library.MagickSetBackgroundColor(self.wand, bg.resource)
```

This _can_ conflicts with a few decoder delegates, and has some odd behavior with ImageMagick-7 that results in "blank" images.

Ideally, the `background=...` parameter should be respected, rather than a hard coded value. This allows users of vector formats to set canvas colors -- like #360.

Leaving the background unset, by default, also prevents corruption issues with newer versions  PDF/TIFF libraries -- like #384, and #352.

items.title: OSError importing wand.image on Termux (missing glibc)
items.body:
On [Termux](https://termux.com/), I get the following traceback:

```
>>> import wand.image
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File ".venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/wand/image.py", line 19, in <module>
    from .api import libc, libmagick, library
  File ".venv/lib/python3.7/site-packages/wand/api.py", line 221, in <module>
    libc = ctypes.cdll.LoadLibrary('libc.so.6')
  File "/data/data/com.termux/files/usr/lib/python3.7/ctypes/__init__.py", line 434, in LoadLibrary
    return self._dlltype(name)
  File "/data/data/com.termux/files/usr/lib/python3.7/ctypes/__init__.py", line 356, in __init__
    self._handle = _dlopen(self._name, mode)
OSError: dlopen failed: library "libc.so.6" not found
```
This makes sense as Termux does not provide glibc.

Wand version: 0.5.2
Python version: 3.7.3

The offending code appears to be here: https://github.com/emcconville/wand/blob/6f305a9e28e295d6c863c4eff4cf6c2b5e039a71/wand/api.py#L218-L221

Indeed, changing sys.platform to `'freebsd'` and then running the import, does work. Is there any reason that the generic libc is only used on FreeBSD and DragonFly BSD? Perhaps ctypes.util.find_library('c') could be used every time? Or, maybe ImportError could be raised when an OSError is encountered here?

Hey, folks. I've tried using the histogram function for a picture and hit some rough edges. First, simply accessing it leaks resources, which is reproducible with the following program

n = 8

  for _ in range(n):
    _ = img.histogram
```

I've also tried swapping the order of "with" and "for". The issue seems to be that a 'PixelWand' object is initialized with the object and never properly handled at https://github.com/emcconville/wand/blob/8fa7501187a6379aba2a7935095467e55c347434/wand/image.py#L5585.

The other issue is that I can't even iterate over the values of this histogram:

```
from collections import Counter
with Image(filename='tests/assets/beach.jpg') as img:

items.title: Looking for new maintainers of the project
items.body:
tl;dr: I am looking for people who will maintain the Wand project, and hope to transfer my ownership and permissions to them.

I am a creator of Wand, and have been a maintainer of Wand.  The Wand project had started since about 2011–2012.  At that time I worked for a fashion social media company, which dealt with a lot of photos.  I had used PIL (that Pillow is forked from) for the job, but it had mostly abandoned back then, and when I tried PyPy, PIL was not well compiled with it (at that time PyPy's cpyext was not that compatible to CPython's C API), so I decided to make a `ctypes`-based imaging library which borrows many features from ImageMagick.  The whole time I was working for the company I had been active on Wand, because I treated it as a part of the full-time job.

Even after I quit the work, I still had used Wand for some years, though my new jobs didn't deal with many images so that the most of the image processing was merely resize and clip things. PIL was still not maintained at all until Pillow came out, the situation justified use of Wand for imaging in Python.

Finally, folks (I believe they are not the same people who made PIL) started to maintain PIL again, with rebranded as Pillow. It had some good points such as it worked well with a lot of legacy codes used PIL. My coworkers started to ask me about the reason why we still had to use Wand instead of Pillow. Indeed, we didn't use unique features of Wand, so unanswerable myself.

More and more I've become far from image processing.  All I've done are resizing and clipping.  Pillow works well for the job.  Although I believe Wand still has a niche, I myself have no chance to use its unique functions anymore.  This situation has made me less and less contribute to the project.  I have not even caught updates from ImageMagick 7.

So I now am looking for new people who will maintain the Wand project.  I hope to transfer my ownership and permissions on the project.  These include:

- This GitHub repository
- Wand project on PyPI <https://pypi.org/project/Wand/>
- Wand on ReadTheDocs.org <http://readthedocs.org/projects/wand/> (docs.wand-py.org)
- wand-py.org domain name
- #wand channel on freenode (IRC)
- and other things I missed here

Any opinions and questions are welcome.

items.title: Option to save png without date
items.body: Despite having called `.strip()` on the images, `wand` always saves pngs with `date-create` and `date-modify` timestamps. This introduces a nondeterministic element into the files. According to [this post](https://www.imagemagick.org/discourse-server/viewtopic.php?t=21711), `convert` can accept a `-define png:exclude-chunks=date` setting to modify its behavior. The equivalent call for C would be [MagickSetImageArtifact](https://www.imagemagick.org/api/magick-property.php#MagickSetImageArtifact)(wand, "png:exclude-chunks", "date").

items.title: Crop by bigger frame wraps offset when geometry is set
items.body:
I guess [this code][1] is supposed to handle negative `left`/`top` parameters as offset from right/bottom border of the image, however it interferes with [that code][2] few lines above which automatically computes `left`/`top` from gravity. So when say requested `width` is bigger then source image width, `left` first becomes negative, then wraps around and only part of original image remains after crop.

I suggest you add `max(0, ...)` construct to [code which computes left/right][2] to resolve this.

[1]:https://github.com/dahlia/wand/blob/4fe2c6ba9cb0d4105361cea6e9e9e83116080473/wand/image.py#L1495
[2]:https://github.com/dahlia/wand/blob/4fe2c6ba9cb0d4105361cea6e9e9e83116080473/wand/image.py#L1483
